content.raw:
I'm not sure about the print.

If I'm not wrong the launch_constellation will execute _api_post(), that may raise an exception or return r.json(). I'd suggest to capture the exception to be able to launch the rest of baby cloudsims and only print an error message if the returned code represents a fail (or the exception is raised).

content.raw:
Does it make sense to have the IP and constellation name hard-coded here?

Is it possible to launch the papa cloudsim with a well-known tag, and then use this tag to get the IP and constellation name?
content.html:
Does it make sense to have the IP and constellation name hard-coded here?

Is it possible to launch the papa cloudsim with a well-known tag, and then use this tag to get the IP and constellation name?

content.raw: Not at the moment. We could wait for a new machine to be detected, and check that it is ready, and use the information for the next step(s). This will probably be done as part of the Jenkins integration.
content.html: Not at the moment. We could wait for a new machine to be detected, and check that it is ready, and use the information for the next step(s). This will probably be done as part of the Jenkins integration.

content.raw:
I'm not sure about the print.
If I'm not wrong the launch_constellation will execute _api_post(), that may raise an exception or return r.json(). I'd suggest to capture the exception to be able to launch the rest of baby cloudsims and only print an error message if the returned code represents a fail (or the exception is raised).

I'd suggest to capture the exception to be able to launch the rest of baby cloudsims and only print an error message if the returned code represents a fail (or the exception is raised).

content.raw: It looks good to me, besides two minor comments. As a side note, I believe our code would improve a lot if we start to become strict with the docstring. I'd suggest to write a description for every function, as well as a brief description of its arguments and what type is required.
content.html: It looks good to me, besides two minor comments. As a side note, I believe our code would improve a lot if we start to become strict with the docstring. I'd suggest to write a description for every function, as well as a brief description of its arguments and what type is required.

content.raw: I don't agree that all functions should have docstring. I'm not saying that we have enough right now either. Lets ask the others.
content.html: I don't agree that all functions should have docstring. I'm not saying that we have enough right now either. Lets ask the others.

content.raw:
Specially, doc is more useful in python where the type of the parameters and returned values are implicit. Something brief is not so bad.

We could follow this [convention](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0257/).
content.html:
Specially, doc is more useful in python where the type of the parameters and returned values are implicit. Something brief is not so bad.

We could follow this convention.

content.raw:
To avoid a possible (though admittedly very unlikely) race condition in which the same temporary filename gets used in two places, we should tell `tempfile` to not delete the temporary file when it's closed:

        tmp_file = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False)
content.html:
To avoid a possible (though admittedly very unlikely) race condition in which the same temporary filename gets used in two places, we should tell tempfile to not delete the temporary file when it's closed:

    tmp_file = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False)
